text:
Another Julia v1.6 question:

Is it possible to set the stacktrace printing to _not_ use really muted colours for variable names, type params, filenames and line locations? (i think it's maybe `:light_black`, but would prefer e.g. `:normal`)

I find it really hard to read on a dark terminal backround and files/lines info in particular is really useful (and i hit a lot of errors :stuck_out_tongue:)

I'd a quick look in the docs, and in `base/*errorshow.jl*` but couldn't see anything to suggest it could be set

text: There’s a discourse thread with some ways to hack this. But might it be possible to fix your terminal? Many have a “minimum contrast” setting, which can over-ride themes which (for some reason) choose to make this invisible.

text: BTW I think the precedent here was how `@info` et al print line numbers, although they are admittedly less important there. But there aren’t many levels of grey available, it seems a shame if themes make one of them useless.

text:
My terminal looks very similar to the one in the image above. So the colour isn't invisible, it's just hard to read.
I don't really this Base should be so opinionated / should be conservative about dimming text, or at least make it configurable (an almost-black terminal seems pretty usual, I'm not saying that avoiding any clash with any Colo scheme is feasible)

text: OK, your screenshot is easily readable on my screen. Although I’d set the dim a bit brighter, given a slider. In the ultra-long bikeshed thread, it was felt useful to have 3 levels of greyscale importance, and bold/normal/`:light_black` seems to be the only way to get that on both dark and light.
